Award.AwardTitle: Support for Gordon Research Conference on Photonuclear Reactions. Conferece to be held in Holderness, NH August 5-10, 2012
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides partial support of the 2012 Gordon Research Conference on Photonuclear Reactions, which will be held at the Holderness School in Holderness, NH from August 5 - 10, 2012. The Gordon Conference serves as a forum for the presentation of the newest ideas and results in the field, and plays an important role in driving forward theoretical and experimental work on electromagnetic reactions in nuclear physics. Ronald Gilman of Rutgers University, the PI of this proposal, is vice-chair of the meeting. The money will be used to support domestic travel costs and registration fees of junior scientists.

The broader significance of this award is in the training of junior scientists. The participation of junior scientists is a focus of the Gordon Research Conferences organization, with the intent of having the junior scientists interact extensively and develop a network of scientific collaborators, while also developing the breadth and depth of their physics knowledge, leading to greater career achievements. The Gordon Photonuclear Reactions Conferences have been notable for the large attendance of junior scientists. For the 2010 Conference, 41% of attendees were graduate students, and 13% were postdocs. It is very noteworthy that 25% of attendees were women, far in excess of the percentage of women in the field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vast growth in our knowledge of the universe has led to increasing depth and specialization in the knowledge and activities of scientists, and a proliferation of very specialized meetings, for discussions of experts in a sub-speciality of an area of physics. Yet it is important to broadly train younger physicists to have some familiarity with the world wide program in an entire area of physics, and in related fields. For many years the Gordon Research Conference (GRC) on Photonuclear Reactions has served that role for the community of physicists studying topics such as the structure of few body nuclei, hadrons, especially the proton and neutron that make up nuclei, and the theory of quantum chromodynamics and its implications for nuclear structure. Broader meetings, such at the American Physical Society meetings or the International Nuclear Physics Conferences, typically have too many sessions in parallel for much exposure to broader physics areas, have overly filled schedules, and are quite expensive.

The biannual Photonuclear Reactions GRC has thus been the most prominent international meeting -- it traditionally has a large European attendance -- at which young Ph.D. students first make contact with a number of physicists working at other laboratories and a broader range of topics in subatomic physics than they are exposed to at their home institution or laboratory. Having longer talks as compared to, e.g., APS meetings allows ideas and techniques to be presented at greater length, making it more likely that the young scientists will learn something that impacts their research. The format of the conference, with attendees housed together and extended discussion time, also encourages discussions and interactions between the scientists attending. It is well recognized that much of the benefit from attending meetings occurs from conversations outside the formal sessions, e.g., at coffee breaks, which has not been duplicated by remote attendance, through teleconferencing or network applications. The networking with others in particular leads to the Photonuclear Reactions GRC having a much greater impact on scientific careers than typical meetings.

Despite the recognized need for such a meeting, encouraging attendance at the meeting has become more difficult, due to a combination of limited travel funds, along with more travel funds being used for research programs at remote accelerators and travel to specialized meetings. Thus, funding was requested to support young scientists, graduate students and postdocs, enabling them to attend the meeting by reducing the cost to them and supporting research grants.

The funding was used to match other sources of support (e.g., Gordon Research Conferences, Jefferson Science Associates, research grants), allowing us to partially support 11 students and postdocs, on average covering about 50\% of their conference registration and room and board fees. All of the individuals supported by this grant were involved in research projects related to the Jefferson Laboratory physics program; Jefferson Lab in Newport News, Virginia, hosts the 6-GeV Continuous Electron Beam Accelerator Facility, which is at present the leading facility in the world for the research covered at the Photonuclear Reactions GRC. In keeping with the international character of the Photonuclear Reactions Conference, the individuals supported came from eight American and two international institutions (both Israeli). Eight of the 11 young scientists gave poster presentations at the meeting, and one gave a 20-minute talk.

The meeting was a very good experience for the young scientists.
